texto:
Across the U.S., nights are warming faster than days because of climate change. That effect is amplified in cities as many become more urbanized.

New York Times readers shared their experiences of this unusually hot summer. Join the conversation: https://nyti.ms/3hX9pHF

President Emmanuel Macron of France said that French military forces had killed the leader of the Islamic State in the Greater Sahara, Adnan Abu Walid al-Sahraoui.

NYTIMES.COM

How many words can you make with 7 letters? Try today‚Äôs Spelling Bee.

Don‚Äôt forget, your words must include the center letter.

These burritos filled with soft scrambled eggs, scallion-flecked refried beans and buttery avocado slices are great any time of the day.

Gabrielle Petito and her fianc√©, Brian Laundrie, left on July 2 for an adventure in their outfitted van. Now, the police say, she is missing and her fianc√© is ‚Äúa person of interest‚Äù in her disappearance.

Struggle for Control of Afghanistan Comes to K Street

NYTIMES.COM
Why Australia Bet the House on Lasting American Power in Asia

Philippines Is Defiant as Hague Court Announces Full Drug War Inquiry

A court ruled that President Joko Widodo of Indonesia and six other top officials had neglected to fulfill citizens‚Äô rights to clean air and ordered them to improve the poor air quality in Jakarta.

The four-person crew of SpaceX‚Äôs Inspiration4 raised the number of people in space to 14, edging out a 2009 record.

NYTIMES.COM
More people are in space right now than ever before.

The hunting of whales and dolphins is a centuries-old custom in the Faroe Islands. But the killing of more than 1,400 white-sided dolphins last weekend prompted outrage among activists and and upset even supporters of the cultural practice.

NYTIMES.COM
1,400 Dolphins Were Killed in Faroe Islands. Even Hunting Supporters Were Upset.

The only exit poll from California‚Äôs recall election showed Gavin Newsom winning with an unusual coalition: Longstanding racial and ethnic divides between white voters and voters of color seemed to vanish.

NYTIMES.COM
What the exit polling tells us about the California electorate, and why it might be wrong.

NYTIMES.COM
Opinion | How Cryptocurrency Can Keep Americans Free

Gov. Gavin Newsom of California emerged from the recall victorious. But he still has multiple crises to confront ‚Äî a punishing drought, rising home prices, homelessness and a pandemic-ravaged education system.

Newsom Beat the Recall, Now Comes the Hard Part: Governing California

A SpaceX rocket lifted off carrying four Americans to orbit the Earth for three days. The mission, known as Inspiration4, is the first orbital trip where not one of the people aboard is a professional astronaut.

NYTIMES.COM
SpaceX Launches Astronaut Crew Like No Other on Orbital Adventure

New York Times photographers around the U.S. spent the past six months documenting the coronavirus economy. As its path veered, so did our sense of where the finish line was.

America‚Äôs Grand Reopening, Postponed

As a coronavirus vaccination mandate for health workers went into effect in France on Wednesday, officials said that some were still holding out against the obligation. Under a new law passed, nearly 3 millionM√°s people who work in health care or other essential fields must get at least a first shot or face job suspensions without pay.

NYTIMES.COM
A vaccine mandate goes into effect for French health workers, but some are holding out.

President Biden will virtually convene on Friday some of the leaders of the nations most responsible for climate change, urging them to do more to slash greenhouse gas emissions ahead of a critical United Nations summit in November.

NYTIMES.COM
Biden to host leaders to discuss climate change ahead of a U.N. summit.

Senators introduced a bipartisan bill that would create a pathway to citizenship for some children and young adults who were raised in the U.S. but face deportation at age 21.

NYTIMES.COM
Congress pushes for a path to citizenship for ‚Äòdocumented Dreamers.‚Äô

Update: Alex Murdaugh, a prominent South Carolina lawyer who is at the center of multiple investigations after his wife and son were shot and killed at the family‚Äôs home in June, plans to turn himself in onM√°s Thursday on charges that he staged his own assassination, even as he continued to deny any involvement in the killing of his family.

NYTIMES.COM
Alex Murdaugh to Surrender for Staging His Own Killing

Health officials are investigating a cluster of at least 16 Covid cases linked to an electronic music festival earlier this month on Randalls Island in New York City and urging everyone who attended the event to get tested.

NYTIMES.COM
Officials connect 16 Covid cases to NYC‚Äôs Electric Zoo music festival.

Los Angeles County next month will require proof of coronavirus vaccination to enter bars, nightclubs and other drinking establishments, as it joins the list of places putting pressure on people to get vaccinated.

NYTIMES.COM
L.A. County will require proof of vaccination at drinking establishments.

Pope Francis urged people to get vaccinated against Covid-19, adding that it was ‚Äúironic‚Äù that a cardinal who was not vaccinated had been hospitalized with the virus. He seemed to be referring to an AmericanM√°s cardinal, Raymond Burke, Ôªøwho spread vaccine misinformation and then was treated for Covid-19 at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota.

NYTIMES.COM
Pope urges everyone to get a Covid vaccine.

The Brazil Senate and Supreme Court nullified rules that President Jair Bolsonaro issued last week banning social networks from removing what they judge to be disinformation about the coming presidential election.

Bolsonaro‚Äôs Ban on Removing Social Media Posts Is Overturned in Brazil

NYTIMES.COM
Police in Aurora, Colo., Engaged in Racially Biased Policing, Investigation Finds

John Durham, the special counsel appointed by the Trump administration to scrutinize the Russia investigation, will ask a grand jury to indict Michael Sussmann, a cybersecurity lawyer, on a charge of making a false statement to the FBI. An indictment is likely to attract significant political attention.

How much did California's recall election cost?

The state estimated $276 million. But including the money spent on campaigns, the total cost would be closer to half a billion dollars, one expert said.

How much was spent on the recall? One estimate: Nearly half a billion dollars.

Much of what we thought we knew about metabolism was wrong, a paper published last month in Science by more than 80 co-authors revealed. Using previously collected data from more than 6,400 subjects who rangedM√°s in age from 8 days to 95 years, and adjusting for body size and the amount of fat and muscle present, they found that our metabolism generally goes through four distinct life phases.

NYTIMES.COM
The New Science on How We Burn Calories

Gavin Newsom was elected governor of California in 2018 by a wide margin. Three years later, voters who voted no on a Republican-led recall effort largely mirrored the partisan lines of that race.

Simone Biles and other elite gymnasts told senators that the system "enabled and perpetrated" Larry Nassar‚Äôs sexual abuse in emotional testimony on Wednesday. The FBI director apologized to the victims for the agency‚Äôs mishandling of the case. https://nyti.ms/2YV14gF

As readers rushed to buy books about race and racism last year, publishers rushed to sign deals to publish more. Those books are now being released, and the publishing world is anxious to see what their successes or failures might mean for future deals. https://nyti.ms/3nAVtXp

NYTIMES.COM
Books on Race Filled Best-Seller Lists Last Year. Publishers Took Notice.

‚ÄúI have never refused the Eucharist to anyone,‚Äù Pope Francis said on Wednesday, when asked about U.S. bishops considering denying Communion to politicians, like President Biden, who support abortion rights. Bishops should be pastors, not politicians, Francis said.

The mathematician Ingrid Daubechies‚Äô pioneering work in signal processing helped make our electronic world possible ‚Äî and beat a path for women in the field. Her female students mention her willingness to pushM√°s for child care at conferences, and sometimes even to take on babysitting duties herself. ‚ÄúMy adviser volunteered to entertain my toddler while I gave a talk,‚Äù one of her former Ph.D. students recalls. ‚ÄúShe seamlessly included all aspects of work and life.‚Äù

NYTIMES.COM
The Godmother of the Digital Image
